I do not agree with the negative reviews of this film. Yes, you can debate the technical aspects of high and low tide together with ocean currents and depths and shark behaviour all day but this is a movie and not a science documentary. I hadn't heard of this film and so I was not sure what to expect. I was however hooked from the very beginning and found it very enjoyable. There have been films that are similar to the classic 'Jaws" over the years but this film brought back memories of watching Jaws as a child. The camerawork, pace and characters are superb and I found myself constantly trying to work out the characters next move. As I say, it is easy to pick faults in the technical aspects of a film and it might not be to everyone's taste but I very much enjoyed watching this and would certainly recommend it.

I laughed from the discontinuity of the waves and vistas (islands one minute, open ocean the next) to a whale carcass resembling a pool toy (that didn't float with the tide) to a critter that didn't find free food in abundance preferable to molesting a skinny (really skinny) human at night, right down to a deeeep dive with no ear equalizing...a waste of time. Rent "Open Water" instead and be truly horrified.

Shortly after the death of her mother, medical student Nancy Adams travels to a secluded beach in Mexico to surf, which is also the same beach her mother surfed at after finding out she was pregnant with Nancy many years before. Despite the danger of surfing alone, Nancy decides to soak up the sun and hit the waves. Suddenly, a great white shark attack, forcing her to swim to a giant rock for safety. Left injured and stranded 200 yards from shore, the frightened young woman must fight for her life as the deadly predator circles her in its feeding ground. I really like this movie because this movie has a good plot, actions, lighting, angles etc. I like the part when Nancy retrieves the GoPro camera helmet from one of the men when he tries to swim to the rock, and after another close attack from the shark records a message for her father and sister, and then throws the helmet toward the shore. The GoPro camera is found floating near the shore by Carlos' son, who brings his father to the beach. Carlos then finds Nancy floating in the shallows as his son runs for help. Overall this movie is very good the actors did a very good job with their roles and contribution. Also, the director was successful to help the actors act their roles better. I would recommend this movie to people who enjoy thriller and action.

I dont mind inconsistencies if it is humorous but this movie takes itself serious.Big plus on the visuals though, nice butt, cool shark and fine waves;)

I'm willing to suspend belief while watching a B-Movie with an absurd and implausible screenplay, but this one went so far beyond what a movie can get away with while still taking itself seriously, that I'm stunned it wasn't universally panned.Blake lively cops a shark bite and spends the movie stranded on a rock. The main problem? That same shark, which for some reason was portrayed as being maybe 12 feet long when it gave her the equivalent of a nip, suddenly turns into a giant megalodon capable of flipping a large whale carcass, tearing 3 other people in half like they were bite-sized nibbles, literally sawing through and shredding the metal framework of a buoy as if it were butter before the laugh-out-loud moment at the climax where it swims with the momentum of a steam train into the ocean floor.There are a myriad of other problems, such as when they try to posit that the shark has an aversion to jellyfish, which sharks don't. Unless they got stinging tendrils directly in their eye, which would be easily avoided thanks to the membranes that cover and protect their eyes, the shark wouldn't even feel a jellyfish nor be phased by some stinging coral. And that's the least of the scientifically inaccurate liberties the movie took.It's taken decades for the general public to overcome the misconceptions about sharks created by films like Jaws, then this absolute turd of a movie comes along and tries to portray one as a vengeful monster that's been wronged by humans (a hook hanging out of it's mouth) and is now on a single-minded vendetta to stalk and kill people for the sport of it.The script is a dud, with some cringey 'mom died so daughter goes in search of the spirit of adventure at some beach the mom loved to pay homage while making a life decision about whether or not to be a doctor' unnecessarily crammed in there to try to lend emotional gravity where there is none. The only redeeming feature is Steven Seagull. He's the only character the audience could be reasonably expected to invest and care in. From the constant idiocy of the protagonist, to the idiocy of the shark's victims, to the CPR-ignorant savior; the movie is easily one of the worst films I've seen in years. At least Sharknado had the decency to not take itself seriously. This movie tries it's best to be a suspenseful thriller but ends up falling into the category of "so bad it's not good or bad, just a waste of a budget and the audience's time".Avoid this steamer like you would a rotting whale carcass.

Review title: Brilliant idea ruined by over the top Hollywood ending.
Review_body: I won't lie, I had high hopes for this film. Blake Lively openly stated that hubby Ryan Reynolds largely ignored thriller Buried was her motivation for doing The Shallows. That coupled with the promise of an Open Water / Jaws "less is more" atmosphere was enough to sucker me in. And for the first half, it delivers. Everything in the first 30 minutes of this film seems plausible to a non surfer like myself. Granted it's the worst case scenario, but none the less it all seems very possible. Shark attacks are rarely fatal (sharks do not EAT people), high and low tides can change the geography of the sea on an hourly basis, and people DO get stranded at sea. Fine. So far so good. Then it all goes a bit........... Matrix-esque, as Blake Lively suddenly seems to be able to bend nature against its will. She also manages to go from being at deaths door from dehydration, shock, and insetting gangrene, to being able to out swim, outsmart, and generally outdo a great white shark, all while being immune to jellyfish stings, blood loss, sunstroke and um.....drowning. She also seems to have perfect vision underwater. But this is not a one sided battle, Mrs Van Wilder is equally matched by natures perfect killing machine, Agent Shark. Who it seems can also bend the rules of nature, as well as shark-kind (thankfully though we're spared any jaws sequel style "roaring", or Deep Blue Sea backwards swimming, which even I know is impossible). It really is a shame, because this could have been a great psychological thriller, amping up the tension from a slow circling predator that's simply biding it's time waiting for its prey to run out of options and just take a leap of faith. Sort of a Blair Sea Witch. That's not to say it doesn't have its moments. The shot of the sharks silhouette behind the surfed wave is genuinely unnerving and exciting. As are the overhead shots of it circling Mrs Deadpool. Even the jump scare Go Pro opening is well done. But it's all for nothing due to the infuriating second half, where we simply see way to much of the shark way too early. For a film that's well under 90 minutes, the shark gets a surprising amount of broad daylight screen time. And that's what really robs this film of its integrity. That and the ridiculous "disposal" of Agent Shark, who suffers a death so preposterous you'll be shocked for a few seconds (due to some pretty well placed timing by the editor), and then find yourself laughing at the sheer absurdity of it. All in all this had the chance to be a major contender, it really does start well, and even tags a moment of truth in its last scene by inferring that surfers who are attacked by sharks do go back in the water. Sadly though coming back to reality for the last two minutes can't excuse the over the top second half, poor CGI backgrounds (that stand out a mile on Blu Ray, let alone 4K), and a general waste of a very good idea.

Review title: Could have been a good movie...
Review_body: ...but instead, it's mediocre.First the positive things: Blake Lively does a decent job on this one, just as Steven "Sully" Seagull, who's the secret star in this movie. The cinematography is very good, at some points really impressive.On the other hand, there is a (especially in the second half of the movie) bad script, and with bad I mean really bad. The final sequences with the poorly looking CGI-shark are just ridiculous and gives you some face-palming WTF moments.But all in all, you can watch the movie for it's beautiful scenery and imagery. The trailer looked good and who doesn't like a good scary movie with a shark and a beautiful woman? The Shallows had the shark and the woman but failed big time everywhere else.Blake Lively possesses everything that any superficial male would appreciate. For that reason alone, I didn't give this movie a 0. Why did she agree to do this movie? This cannot be good for her career. Anyone's career. Her acting was horrific but I doubt any actor could have looked good in this horrible script. I can only imagine how Blake Lively must have cringed while watch this movie. The only bright spot for her must be that once she's older, she can look back to this movie and remember how gorgeous she was. This movie was so bad it was laughable. A complete waste of time.

I only gave it 2 stars because of the Steven Seagull and some of the pictures. The biggest shallow of the movie is in its plot. It is boring, predictable and unbelievably kitsch. The amount of nonsense is just overwhelming to the point where it unintentionally becomes a comedy.

I almost didn't watch this movie due to the negative comments on here. So glad I did. I now realise the majority of negative reviews are completely dull, nit picking and also so snobby. Are you really watching a shark movie imagining a groundbreaking, life affirming film that also manages to show shark attacks as accurate reality? Most negatives are about the unrealistic nature of the shark, and poor use of CGI. Perhaps in the final part of the film, this is true. However the tension was so well developed by then it doesn't matter, you see the actual shark fleetingly and in very fast paced scenes so whoever really has time to pause the movie, get your magnifying glass out for a close inspection and dwell on this has to much time on their hands. The shots of the ocean, beach and surfing are utterly stunning, combined with a great soundtrack. Blake Is surprisingly good and more than able to command your attention, being on screen for 95% of the movie, for the duration. The tension is well portrayed as you will be going through various scenarios/outcomes/plans yourself in your own head, and her actions are all cleverly thought out- seeing as she has more then enough time on your hands, being stranded on a rock, is more than plausible. The review under this slated the movie for showing her resorting to eating a crab! Oh my, shock horror! Well actually- she spat the crab out to feed the seagull. And YES, you would be more than hungry, lying in full beam of the sun, injured, already having surfed all day and swam for your life, so to criticise this is ridiculous. Give it a try, Im glad I did.

Review title: I don't know why but loved it
Review_body:
Not much to say actually, just a boring Sunday afternoon nothing to do and who knows why I choose this move to watch. It was perfect on a rainy day though. I never liked "shark movies" before but this one is pretty good.
Don't think it's an academy award film and expect more than a movie to watch once and forget it, but I wanted to give it 10.

I signed up for this account just to post a review of this movie. I give it a solid 7 out of 10. The reason I signed up to give a review of this movie? It could have been a slam dunk 10 out of 10... If not for the last 15 minutes.The ending lacked the same fervor and caliber as the first 90% of the movie. They did a lot of things right- they kept the shark to a minimum, they built suspense. Blake was amazing- she carried the movie, and I never felt bored. She was the only main character on screen for the whole time- and she never disappointed me. ***BIG SPOILER ALERT WITH THE ENDING***The end? Ruined it for me. From out of nowhere came really bad CGI, and an incredibly unrealistic ending. The first part of the movie made this worthy of an impending Oscar. The last 10-15 minutes, the ending- sucked. The ending would have been better if they left things unresolved, had her eaten, or just left her on the rock.I could see Lively winning a best actress award, and the movie winning best picture- If they followed through on the first 90% of the movie.The ending ruined this movie- but I still recommend it because of the fact that 90% of this movie was pretty good.I'm a nobody, I have zero experience in the film industry- I could have written a better ending on my lunch hour than they gave to the public. All in all, it's a 7 out of 10. Could have been a 10 out of 10 though- and that's frustrating. They should have panned out with her on the rock and left the viewers to their imagination. That might have made this movie Oscar worthy.

No spoilers. I really did enjoy this movie. I have only been to a few films this year in a theater. I don't go often because I find a lot of what's out there is total crap. But I digress.The shallows delivers a survival story of a determined young woman who goes to an unnamed beach on the coast of Mexico, and fights for her life. Blake Lively's performance as Nancy Adams is convincing and keeps the movie "afloat". Films like this require a strong lead character, and actor, or else it just won't work. Much of the film rests on Blake's performance, as most of the movie is the character Nancy stuck on a small rock. Blake doesn't disappoint. The rock plays just as big a role. Though lifeless and inanimate it serves it's purpose, Blake knew what to do, like when she worked on "Gossip girl" with Leighton Meester (hint hint hint hint hint hint). I found it harsh some critics who said Blake's performance was a surprise. She's a great actress, and this film shows she can hold our attention. She has that "it" factor that makes people like me-who seldom go see films in the theater-get up and open our wallets. I had a great time.

I hadn't heard much hype about this film as all I had seen were a couple of trailers before other movies in the cinema so I wasn't sure what to expect. The main attraction to this film was that Blake Lively was starring in it and also the fact that everybody loves a good shark thriller and there hadn't been any successful ones made in years. I would never have put Blake Lively as 'serious' actress but after seeing The Shallows I feel that she really proves herself as a well capable actress. Taking into consideration that Blake is the only actor with any screen-time bar a couple of minutes at the very beginning, she did an unbelievable job and I feel it was an outstanding performance reminiscent of Tom Hanks in Castaway and Leonardo DiCaprio in The Revenant. Movies where there is one actor on screen for the majority of the running time with very little dialogue, are very tricky, as the single actor has to keep the audience interested on their own for the duration of the movie. Blake did this precisely and as an audience member, I feel like she really captured the authenticity of what we as humans endure, to survive and how adrenaline gives us our superhuman abilities in abnormal circumstances. I think Lively's performance is fair to compare to Oscar-winning actor's DiCaprio and Hanks as she did just as good a job but will not get the recognition she deserves. If it is the fact that she is a woman I do not know, but I feel her performance was flawless and proved that female actors are just as capable as men to carry an entire movie on their own.A flaw I found with the movie was the CGI of the shark itself. It looks fake and computerised which ruined the effects for me and I was taken out of the realness I had previously felt while. The special FX look like they would have been remarkable back in 2002 however, not up to 2016 standard which I found extremely disappointing. Regardless of that, something that did impress was the breathtaking cinematography of the waves and movements of Blake and her fellow actors being attacked by the shark as well as being pulled by the undercurrents of the water. This was true cine- magic and I found myself constantly asking '"how the hell did they film that?" throughout the movie.Overall, Blake Lively was really what did it for me and in my opinion it was a real breakthrough performance which put her up on a pedestal with the likes of Reese Witherspoon, Sandra Bullock and Jennifer Connolly, to name a few. Acting was consistent throughout and although the shark was not as 'real' as I had hoped there were still many jumpy bits that had me on the edge of my seat.

Review title: The best shark movie I've seen
Review_body: A big con of this movie, is the trailer. Once you've seen it, you'll have plenty of moments in the movie that you'll recognize and probably know what's going to happen next. Nevertheless if you compare this movie with number of other shark movies, I'm sure you'll like this one most. The way Blake Lively is able to play as main character is insane! The movie contains just a small amount of actors, and is slowly starting. The movie plays in a small setting, but there are plenty factors to make it interesting. Since she is trapped on a small stone near the cost, she is not able to speak to anyone, that could make the film boring, but it is the opposite. Mimicry is one of the most important things in the movie and Blake really nails it! It is a cat and mouse game between her and the shark, and the end is a bit weird, but surprising.
...it's a beautiful surfer girl versus a fake shark. Blake Lively makes it work because she's totally committed to the preposterous premise. It's a fun movie!

I liked the suspense you could feel when the shark was around, but at the same time, the shark seemed too dedicated to hunt and kill this specific lady. Especially when there is a giant whale lying dead a few yards away from the rock. It gets to a point where the shark is ready to do anything to eat this lady, I get a Jaws 3 feeling where the shark traveled to the Bahamas just to try to kill these people. The end really threw me off, It was such an unrealistic ending, she knew that the sharpy thing was there and that the shark was going to follow her all the way down to the bottom and die. Not taking into consideration that if the shark didn't follow her or if it attacked in another angle she would have been shark food.All and all I would not recommend this movie if you want to see a human vs animal thriller. But if you want to see some fun, fast-paced, shark attack scenes, sure.

I thought Blake Lively was just another pretty face but she played a very credibly role as Nancy Adams in this movie. Was a bit apprehensive about how this movie would play out. One of the best shark movies I have ever seen, considering they are all bad. This one is actually good, probably because Blake Lively is a great actress

The Shallows is a cinematic masterpiece that will have you on the edge of your seat. Blake Lively plays a girl named Nancy, who is stranded on a rock in the middle of the ocean in this human vs. shark thriller. Lively's acting is quite admirable, I could feel her despair and loneliness through the screen. Not only is the acting fantastic, but the amount of stress is addicting. I enjoyed the feeling of not knowing, and the need to survive. This film presented an adventure that one can only enjoy by watching this motion picture.

Movie: The Shallows Feeling as the credits roll: Loved It, Scared to Surf, Good Movie. Movie Rating: 8.0/10 Soundtrack Rating: 7.0/10Watch in IMAX?: Not essential. Not filmed with IMAX camera's. Watch in 3D? Not essential. Not filmed with 3D camera's.Movie Review:I was immediately brought into the story as the main actress, played by Blake Lively, is on her way to a remote beach she had never been, but always dreamed of going to. Within the first couple minutes of the film, you're on the beach. There are very few actors in this movie, and so the story and what is going on is easy to follow. As far as a perfect "arc" goes, The Shallows takes you for a hell of a ride, from the first shot, to the last. I was scared. I knew the whole time what was initially going to happen, but not how it was going to happen (I'm sorry, if you didn't know already, this film is based on a shark attack(s)). It was riveting, suspenseful, and man, I've got to admit, Blake Lively was hot. If the storyline, music, and scenery wasn't already enough, you've got 90 minutes to watch this actress shine. And I mean shine.Though I love any film shot on a beach, and had a feeling I was going to like this movie, I am still slightly shocked as to how good The Shallows is. A simple storyline, with minimal to no graphics (Other than the shark scenes), this movie feels real. Nothing to distract you, other than Blake Lively, but she brings you right into the story. And the closer to the story you get, the scarier it is when the shark is lurking. Don't kid yourself, this beautifully shot shark attack movie has got it all. And though the sun is shimmering most of the time, it is a horror flick. So be prepared to jump. I am seriously not sure how much I want to surf again. I've already had a couple fears while in the water hanging onto my board, but this is to a whole new level. That being said, I was inspired at the end of the film, and will get back in that water again. Not to mention, Rob Stewarts documentary, Sharkwater. If you've been scared of sharks because of the media and movies like The Shallows, watch Sharkwater. It will change your view of sharks and you won't be scared of these beautiful creatures in everyday real ocean life.Go see The Shallows. See it in theatres. The Big Screen really allows the shark scenes to jump out at you, the music rumbles in the theatre, and Blake Lively gives a great performance. Awesome movie, great horror flick, and yet still makes you want to go to a remote beach. But maybe not jump into the water. . .Soundtrack Review: Original Music by: Marco BeltramiThere was nothing spectacular about the soundtrack, but it certainly played to the scenes very well. The composer created fear, love and every other emotion you were meant to hear and feel, perfectly. I would not buy this soundtrack to listen to for fun, but it melded with the story and movie fantastically. Overall great soundtrack for The Shallows.

Good acting, good directing, good atmosphere and even the music fits - but loads of clichés. Blake is convincing in the role. However the camera simply HAS to focus on her female attributes - perhaps a fraction of a second too long sometimes ;) Especially the scene of the final moments of the human-shark final battle is lame - such a Hollywood scene should be forbidden by law in the year 2016 :) Come on, guys, did you write the script in the 1980s? And yes, I am still talking about the shark-human final stand scene. But I enjoyed the movie all the same. If you are into shark thrillers, this is definitely one to watch, but remember to turn the cliché filters on ;)

Review_body: It doesn't get much better than this . Lots of people get eaten despite the fact there is a dead whale main course floating around nearby. I don't care though she is so fit .

Review title: Best seagull in a supporting role
Review_body: Less Jaws, more Gravity, with Blake Lively thinking her way out of a tight spot.I don't think the bikini bits are gratuitous. Watch any surfer film with women. It's just what they wear. Passes the Bechdel test.A shade under 90 minutes, which is remarkable these days.

Review title: Awful plot line, decent CGI sequences
Review_body: The stupidly unrealistic things in this movie significantly distracted from my being able to enjoy it.The overarching problem for me was the bizarre dichotomy of the main (and pretty much only) character who is supposed to be very intelligent but keeps making bad decisions that any normal person would not. We're told she made it quite a ways through med school before taking break for a while. Med school is incredibly difficult and if someone gets in and makes it most of the way through and takes a break voluntarily, they are most certainly are not stupid.First stupid thing...the movie opens with her driving in a remote area of Mexico on a desolate road in an old truck alone with middle aged Mexican man she just met. How many intelligent mid 20's attractive American women are going to hop in a truck, by themselves, to reach a remote hidden beach that a strange man in a beat up truck who claims to know where it is? Any women with a half a brain isn't going to do that, let alone one smart enough to be in med school.It just goes on from there with bad decision after bad decision. How about this one, you see a huge dead floating whale, what do you do? We'll our character, a very experienced surfer, decides to swim up to it. No one with a reasonable amount of experience in the ocean is going to swim up to a dead whale carcass. Bad, bad, idea.It just goes on from there.The CGI action sequences were reasonably well done, yes you could tell it was CGI, but it was okay at least. Some of things the CGI whale did however were ridiculous.I only paid $0.99 to watch and still wondered if I paid too much.

Weeeeell... 1) Apparently there is a great cell coverage at the unknown beach in Mexico. 2) A lot, I mean A LOT, unnecessary shots of waves, sea, surfers, protagonist butt and boobs. 3) A shark, who has a mentality of vengeful human, ignoring huge whale carcass nearby and wasting its energy on trying to CRAWL on the rock to hunt a human. No, predators, sharks, do not do that. 4) Huge great white jaws, which can demolish a metal buoy later, leave just a minor flesh wound on woman's leg. 5) Experienced surfers ignore shark warning from a wounded protagonist on a rock. 6) A drunk puts a cell phone in his pants and... immediately goes swimming in those pants. 7) Tides come several times during 24 hours. Yeap, who needs science. 8) Protagonist is some kind of superhuman being. Blood loss for two days? Shark bite? Coral wounds? Jellyfish sting? Dehydration? Heatstroke? She can still beat great white shark in swimming.

Review title: I just felt like she should have lost a limb
Review_body: I love shark horrors and this was good - solid premise, good acting and visual effects and somewhat realistic and horrifying situation. I just felt like the sharks behaviour became too unrealistic towards the end and kinda list me. I missed the suspense of the first half and I feel like with a good shark movie these days it needs to hold onto some sort of realism. I don't think she should have died but she should have lost a limb. Also sharks don't have vocal chords they roar was dumb.

I started with such high hopes for this movie. At first I thought I was going to be a serious drama. But after it pulls you in, it slowly strips you away of any suspension of disbelief you have left until you're shaking head at the end wondering you just wast an hour and a half on this rubbish. Blake was fine. Too bad the writer and director didn't take the movie as serious.

Review title: Best shark movie in a while!
Review_body: I'm coming from the perspective of a shark movie nut. So my review is for those who share this strange obsession!I really enjoyed this film - and by enjoyed I mean it really did what a good shark movie should. Have you sitting there covering your eyes moaning "no no no, I can't look". And yet at the same time make it less drawn out than many do which was refreshing and all the more engaging. Some other positives: -Beautiful setting -Not nearly as cheesy as most shark movies -Decent lead acting and focusing on her as a human being rather than as a sex object which is unusual and refreshing. (By this I mean Blake is a beautiful young woman, but there was a minimal amount of sexual emphasis on this beyond the obligatory bikini boob shot at the start.) I REALLY found this great and such a big step forward! It sets the tone of the movie at a far higher bar than the usual flesh feast shark movies do (HAR HAR) and helps make the whole thing much more believable and serious. -It's scary, did I mention this?! -It felt pretty original as far as shark movies go, with a smart female protagonist and a simple storyOkay so the only bad thing and the reason it wasn't a 10/10 for me: -Just to unrealistic - I don't want to spoil things so I won't go into detail but I feel the story went just a bit too far in the shark's actions. If it had kept to erring on the side of realism it would have been all the more thrilling and in the end make the difference between a shark movie vs. a psychological thriller that isn't in any form unbelievable or silly.Ultimately though I'd 100% recommend this film to any shark movie nut. And to those who aren't, it's worth giving it a go as it's a cut above the rest.

Review title: I was with you until the shark turned into a stalker
Review_body: This movie started out well. A very attractive woman surfing on a beautiful, secluded beach. There was some great cinematography and shots of the area. Blake Lively even seems to be a decent actress.Then the shark stuff starts, and from the very beginning, we have to forget about everything we know about sharks and play pretend. First of all, she really ticks off the shark somehow by disturbing its "feeding grounds." She approaches a dead whale that the shark was feeding on and seems to have offended the shark somehow. So the shark ignores the thousands of pounds of floating, dead meat in the water for the rest of the movie, and pursues the 100 pound surfer girl exclusively.The surfer seeks refuge on the carcass of the whale, then the shark drags a dead whale many times its size further out into the ocean, and seems hell bent on knocking her off. In her escape from the floating whale to a small rock outcropping, she's bitten by the shark, and has some serious wounds from both the bite and coral. The shark is circling her, she's bleeding heavily, and there's no one around who can help.At this point, I'm still willing to forgive the whole shark ignoring the dead whale to pursue a person who isn't even in the water any more. It still felt suspenseful. I wanted her to find a way out and survive. The movie still had my interest and I still cared what happened to her.Then things got real, real stupid. The shark continued to circle, and killed a drunk on the beach who was trying to reach her. Then it killed two other surfers that she'd met the day before. It tried jumping up on the coral to reach her, and pretty much completely stopped acting like a shark. She managed to escape to a buoy as the tide came in, and the shark proceeded to rip the giant, steel buoy to pieces. She shoots the shark with a flare gun then lights whale oil in the water on fire with it, also lighting the shark on fire. I had already written off the movie at this point, but kept watching as I was already close to the end.She then ties herself to the anchor that was holding the buoy in place, and as the shark breaks the chains away she is pulled hundreds of feet under water in the matter of a couple of seconds, and the shark chases her at full speed with reckless abandon to kill her. It ends up impaling itself on the jagged spikes which were apparently part of the anchor.And yea, that was it. A stranded, wounded surfer with nothing kills an over 20 foot long shark by making it chase her into spikes. Dumb.You know what would have been good? A wounded surfer on a small rock outcropping tries to keep her sanity and get help to survive a shark attack. Leave out the dead whale because that kind of made the rest of the movie not make sense. Don't make a wounded, half dead surfer kill a 20+ foot shark, that's not the victory that the movie needed. It would have been sufficient to have her survive. You don't have to schlock it up with the typical Hollywood type ending.Sharks are scary enough, you don't have to make it cartoonish shark with a vendetta against a surfer. Every time the shark did something stupid that a shark would never do, it became less suspenseful. I don't know why they went down that road, but they turned a movie that started out pretty suspenseful into a SciFi Channel made for TV special with a dumb ending.

Review title: Best since Jaws but won't carry it's weight through time like Jaws.
Review_body: Suspenseful? yes, Does Blake look good? yes. *Spoiler* Does Steven "SEAGAL" makes it out alive? HECK YES!!! My favorite part. Him Surviving made it all worthwhile. :POn other notes, I was a little nit picky on a small thing. (Makes me sound like a tight ass, I know. But it crosses my mind and I wonder.) I don't really understand the water levels. (I'm not talking high and low tides . I get that) During the film I get a little thrown off on the depth of the water. One time I feel its super shallow, and the another deep in a similar spot. I understand that there could be sand banks an rocks, but sometimes feel Blake's in shallow-sh water and we get a below shot in the water that perceives to be a lot deeper. I'm not a surfer. So I can't complain. Fun movie though. Are you likely to forget it when a new highly anticipated blockbuster comes out? Probably. Will you still remember Jaws? Yes. Do you hate me answering for you? Probably So... If So.... Shark bite me.

If you have no decent expectations when you are going to see a movie to the cinema and if you do not care about your time at all, then you can watch this kind of movie. The "meat" of this drama, if you will, starts with a 30(?) foot shark choosing the kicking, bony non-natural food item Blake Lively over a lifeless whale carcass that'd be much safer and nutritional to eat. It only goes downhill from there.The shark inexplicably circles an outcropping of rock inexhaustibly, trapping Lively and eschewing its natural inclination to roam the sea in search of prey. Maybe it's the vengeful, near-human obsession with eating this surfer. But for an ocean-going creature, it's oddly clumsy, bumping into nearly everything it comes near. It does manage to nip her on the leg but all's well - not only does the gash nearly instantaneously coagulate and close on its own, she manages to stitch it with a necklace she's been wearing.Meanwhile, Lively manages to stave off her life-threatening hunger after ONE DAY by munching on live crabs and makes a friend of a seagull who - after she fixes its dislocated wing - stays by her side in a show of seeming solidarity. Think Little Mermaid. Several people come to her aid, all to be eaten in gruesome ways because she belongs to the shark, damn it.Inexplicably, Lively decides her salvation lies in reaching the buoy 30 yards further out to sea and makes it by swimming through a neon forest of jellyfish, which she instinctively knows the shark will dislike. Once on the buoy, she unlocks the flare gun box (c'mon, we all know ancient buoys have flare gun boxes) but fails to flag down a passing ship.But all is not lost. Because there's apparently no current in the Pacific ocean, the oil slick leading from the buoy to the dead whale (which the shark has ignored for two days running) is intact and immediately catches fire when a flare is fired into it. This burns the shark but succeeds only in making it angrier. It follows Lively as she sinks impossibly fast to a trench in the ocean ell ahead of the shark, who nonetheless is on her heels. But alas, our clumsy aggressor impales itself on the remnants of the metal buoy it only moments before ripped apart. Lively is washed ashore and rescued by a boy and his father only live to surf another day.Seriously.

This new American classic film on survival from attack of shark will keep your adrenaline flowing till the end of movie. This movie pits a young woman's desire to live against a shark's desire to eat. A mere 200 yards from shore, her short journey to safety becoming the ultimate contest of wills.On one of sunny day she went to beach of Brazil for surfing, little she know that just 200 yards from shore a shark is waiting to kill her. While she been undone on aquatic hover board by shark she quickly reaches in no time on a dead whale to protect herself from deadly shark. Again when been attacked on whale she reaches just in time on big rock for shelter. She is just 200 yards from shore seems very near yet very far. It keep promising hope yet impossible to reach when a shark is wandering around in some particular pattern. Finally she decides to fight against death and makes a master plan to kill shark. The way she executes it on a middle of water where her enemy is one who is in control is magnificent to watch. Despite being injured, she knows her limitation and carefully fight between life and death. Between all these drama audience gets beautiful moments, black lively really takes us to a new level of feeling from where we can take a lesson or two for a life.

The Shallows is a mixed bag of entertainment. At times it feels like your on the cusp of entering the Syfy movie of the week with cheesy CGI and questionable acting and at other times you feel like your watching a genuine suspense thriller.The biggest reason for this back and forth is chiefly due to Directors Jaume Collet-Serra execution of the story. Overall the film is visually beautiful, but scenes tonally shift from one shot to the next. In the first half of the film the shark is seen only in shadows or in a quick cut, and that builds up a lot tension and dread. Yet as we move into the 2nd and 3rd acts; too much of the shark is seen and you begin to lose the suspense because the shark is now literally front and center. Your attention now turns to how the CGI shark looks instead. There are some interesting visual choices on how the characters communicate with each by phone, but it does feel a bit gimmicky.The story is the familiar man (or this case woman) vs nature scenario which is a solid foundation to build a film, but on occasion the plot tends to veer into some questionable Syfy movie of the week territory like finding safety on top of a dead whale :) Blake Lively does a fair job of playing a woman at a crossroads in her life. A subplot involving her relationship with her family is only so-so, where she really shines is are the scenes where she is trapped on this tiny exposed reef. On her own and wounded, isolated by a great white circling around the reef just waiting. You feel Blake's pain, stress, fear, and eventual will to survive all taking place on this one spot. Before and after this though Blake's performance doesn't really stand out.Last but not least is arguably the star of the film, the CGI shark. In short it's not great (no pun intended)and as we move into the final confrontation, between human and shark, the CGI really is at it's worse. CGI shot of Blake's face on an actual surfer is also iffy.The film again has some genuine thrills but not a lot and it's not excessively gory. Also even though the film is just under 90 minutes, it does still feel a little long.I give it 5 stars out of 10

Storyline is masterfully acheived through a resilient performance from Lively. Suspense, stark survival instinct and the will to live make this not just another Shark movie but a blockbuster which will stand the test of time. Perfect Friday night viewing!!

I didn't have high expectations for The Shallows. I simply hoped it would be as tense as Open Water. It didn't quite live up to the latter, but don't dismiss this film as just a run-of-the-mill thriller. It's actually quite a lot better than that.Blake Lively plays our strong, brave, and resourceful heroine, Nancy, an excellent surfer. If I were rating her rather than the film, she'd get a 9.0. Her performance was really admirable, especially when one considers that, just like Tom Hanks in Cast Away, she has to carry 95% of the movie (but more about that later...)The plot is straightforward: while at a beach whose very name is vigorously protected by the locals (to discourage hoards of tourists finding and despoiling their little sandy paradise), Nancy is attacked by a great white shark while surfing.She is more or less trapped on a small rock that will be covered in water by high tide. Now we've got our ticking clock. Not only does she have to stay alive by attending to her shark bite and the elements, but she has to figure a way off the rock before it's too late.Providing more plot details won't enhance your enjoyment of the movie, so that's all I'll mention on the subject.The last scenes of Nancy vs. the shark strain credulity, but we don't care. This is a movie where we simply root for Nancy to survive. I won't say if she does or not. However, despite the overboard girl versus shark climax, I actually came away with a high regard for the film because it did something jaded movie goers don't expect: it impressed me.How did it impress me? The action scenes are so well done that we are drawn into them, rather than passively watching and checking the time on my watch. Once the movie concluded, a few thoughts passed through my mind: how did they film such amazing shark sequences? It has to be a mechanical shark, but it sure looks real. Yeah, they go overboard with it being a super-shark (but still... it's name is the GREAT White Shark!), but that must have been visually stunning in an actual movie theatre (regrettably I saw this as a Netflix movie, on a television screen).I started wondering how they could make the movie look so flawless. They take good advantage of the scenery, the shark, and they keep us totally invested in Nancy's outcome. That's tough to do when she's stuck on a rock for long stretches, but they pull it off nicely.They say a movie is a collaborative effort, and this certainly proves it. Good acting, an amazing director: Jaume Collet-Serra, enviable cinematography, and smart editing keeps us interested.So is this a movie for the ages that you'll be raving about in 20 years. Nope, but it's also doubtful that you'll be bored watching it, which is somewhat of a rarity nowadays, unless your watching some $250 million Marvel comics movie.If you want a pleasant (gripping!) one hour and twenty-six minutes, and liked Open Water, then this is the movie for you.

The film centers around a woman who has recently lost her mother and is going through a time of some drastic life decision making. She decides to visit a secluded beach in Mexico, somewhere her Mother apparently used to visit. After a few hours of surfing with two guys she meets at the beach, the men go back to shore and get ready to go home, leaving Blake Lively alone at sea on her surf board. Before she knows it a shark appears and drags her under water, causing a big gash in Blakes leg. Luckily enough she breaks free and swims to the safety of a nearby badly injured whale, floating out to sea. Holding on to the poor whales fleshy wounds for dear life, she cries out for help hoping the two men would hear her and get help, but sadly for Blake they didn't hear her screams... I won't say anymore about the plot, as that is basically all that's to tell. Yeah their are some deaths along the way, however nothing memorable, as you don't really get to see a second of what's happening, and their wasn't really any character build up to these unfortunate victims, so you don't really care for their demise, although that said, it's still upsetting knowing someone is being eaten by a shark. I refer to the character as Blake Lively, instead of the name of the woman she was playing, because I have no idea what her name was, it was pointed out once or twice I think, but I must not have been paying enough attention. I want to say Rachel, but I also want to say Zoe...Anyway, for the most part of 90 minutes we sit and watch Blake lively have conversations with herself. When shes not talking to herself shes making terrible decisions, or having conversations with a seagull I've named Paul. Paul's really nice, we root for Paul! When you finally get some good close ups of Mr Shark, it leaves you wanting to scream, "WHAT THE HELL, THIS STUFF WAS BETTER IN THE 70's!". The shoddy CGI leaves you feeling as if you are watching a really horrific scene in finding Dory, as the clearly visual affects take you right out of the realness of the made up scenario. As sudden as the film began, the film ends with a miracle fire on water and some very well placed spikes, all just to remind you that yes, another rushed, not very well thought out Hollywood movie, has just taken up another 90 minutes of your life. All criticism aside. I really did enjoy the performance Blake lively gave, even if her character was slightly driving me mad, the film probably wouldn't have been anything if she wasn't good at her job. Oh and Paul the seagull I wish him the best!!

"The Shallows" lured me in with a trailer that does no more than tensely establishing the setup of the film (instead of spoiling every major twist). I was hoping for a clear-cut, slow-burning thriller that plays out in a minimalist yet effective way. What I got was a film that works in principle and is structured rather well, but whose aesthetics and themes are way too blatant.There are surf scenes in a staccato of slow and fast motion, spiced up with soft-techno music, just to hammer home the fact that surfing is supposed to be 'cool'. The character arc of Nancy (Balke Livley) is simple to understand, yet the movie has to remind the audience at least three times quite obviously what its about. And even though the main protagonist looks sexy enough in her bikini and her skintight suit, the camera-work has to stress the curves of her body as to make sure that even the last male and lesbian tongue is lolling. (I have nothing against that, but after a time, the emphasized sexiness felt a little distracting). It seems this movie was made by Captain Obvious, but to my surprise, it was the director of "Non-Stop", "Unknown" and "Run all Night". Subtlety is not a language that "The Shallows" speaks. For me, these elements of the film didn't work that well, but they aren't terrible either.Apart from that, the film can be enjoyed as a nice little B-Picture. Some of the underwater and panorama shots look gorgeous, as does the location on which the movie was filmed. However, the camera work in the beginning is somewhat terrible; the faces of the actors feel too close and the scenes on the beach are more shaky than the scenes in the water. The Film manages to build some nice tension in the middle part and Nancy is quite resourceful and intelligent in her ways to deal with the shark. However, the movie wastes some potential in the finale that is just full of weird coincidences and unbelievable animal behavior.I enjoyed "The Shallows" for what it was and would recommend it to people who like the premise. It definitely has its strengths, but from the aesthetic choices and the way the film talks to its audience, it's clear that it was made with a teenage viewership in mind. And that's fine! However, I didn't enjoy these design decisions as much.

I would have preferred some tear pretend less and some body torn to pieces in more (I'm not cynical, but I did not expect the tears). Removing the dramatic parts, the film has what must have and entertains well despite a few platitudes jump out occasionally. Blake lively is extraordinary and beautiful, the director has it showed... too much

Review_body: I cannot understand how this movie doesn't have a higher overall rating. It's quite realistic, a great thriller, great filming and shots, and keeps you on your feet the entire time! I've watched it over and over again. Love it!!

This is the type of movie that requires that you cannot judge it in the realm of realism. I thought the movie did a great job making you feel uncomfortable with some of the physical horror, it had good surprise scenes that made the audience scream and it did a good job making you feel for Blake Lively's character (Nancy) and hope to see her find a way to shore. To be safe, I'd warn that the rest includes SPOILERS as it touches on aspects of the movie that were not completely shown in trailers. The things I didn't love about the movie included:* Effort to allow for dialog with Nancy talking to herself as a patient was a bit contrived. Not horrible but not great. *I am not a marine biologist by any means but I find it hard to believe that any shark would be drawn away from a whale carcass by a few surfers. At some point the shark would get full and no longer chase prey. The attempt to give the shark a reason to hate humans because of the embedded hook fell short in my opinion. *Again, as a non-marine-biologist, I found it extremely hard to believe that a whale carcass that had been present for less than 24 hours would create enough of a blubber-slick to allow a flare to create a surface fire. *The hardest thing for me to accept was the way that she killed the shark. Maybe it's no more difficult to accept than Brody killing a shark with a giant power cord. But there is no way that that tiny chain would pull Nancy down to the sea floor faster than the animated shark could swim. It was fun to see shark death but I would have preferred to see her release the chain and slowly get closer to shore when the buoy was pushed in by the waves.All in all, I do not regret investing a few dollars and a couple hours to watch this. They kept it simple and it was generally compelling. That said, if I see this movie playing on TV in the future, I will not be drawn in to watch it again.

Review title: The bird was the most interesting character
Review_body:
I watched this because my flatmate had it on and I became intrigued as to how this woman was going to get away from the shark, because it was blatantly obvious she wasn't going to die, so I sat there and watched it all. Turns out I shouldn't have bothered. What tosh!
A woman goes surfing and gets attacked by a shark, she then ends up on a rock and with high tide approaching she has to figure out a way to get off her little rock and back to safety.
The biggest thing that annoyed me was continuity, or lack of. One minute she looks severely dehydrated but then in the next shot she looks absolutely fine... oh, wait... she's dehydrated again! This happens continuously throughout. Another annoyance, which other reviewers have mentioned, is her super human strength! She has a huge gash on her leg and was losing a lot of blood, she had multiple cuts and grazes, gangrene on the gashed leg, several smacks in the arms, legs, face, no water, no food, and no sun lotion!! Yet somehow none of this seemed to affect her and she could still swim (faster than a shark I might add) climb, kick, and flail her arms about at anyone she saw on the shore. Now if that were any normal human being we'd be passed out from blood loss and exhausted from having had no food, water and too much sun!
Overall I really bad movie that wasn't scary, suspended disbelief and continuity errors throughout.
The only redeeming feature was the bird who kept her company.

I watched The Shallows last night, and I was actually quite excited to do that after all the hype it had been receiving and people I know were also mentioning similar good things. Well I can't say they were right and I can't say they were wrong. This movie is a mixed bag and I was watching it with the mindset that people tend to build up movies so much that when you actually do see it, it's underwhelming. I felt that this movie could be one of those cases, so I tried to keep my expectations slightly low.I'll start with what I liked: I thought the set up was kind of interesting, how to keep a wounded woman stuck out in the ocean with land in sight and a shark on her scent, I liked the beginning is the end kind of thing they start with and I liked the fact that there wasn't just a whole bunch of young people around to be shark food. The tension was built up pretty good and had some great moments, but I never truly felt like she (Blake Lively) was in real danger because she is the lead actor. Her performance was very well done for what she was working with, and what straight man wouldn't enjoy seeing her in a very small bikini for 90 minutes. The were a few cool scenes and a scenario with the shark in a wave but there were so many missed opportunities to build up more suspense by having things like that happen more because the shark really doesn't do much.Now to the things I didn't really like: Well I could have done without the tacked on dance tunes and party music that is geared toward the target viewing audience but it took me out of the movie a little. I felt if they left that but took out all the other lame "this is hip now" music they could have a good score that would have added to building the suspense. The other things I didn't like was that the bite on her leg should have been more devastating from a shark that size but I was willing to let that go for the sake of the movie to continue. Also I would have liked to see more overhead shots of the shark circling or just lingering around in the clear water, which would build even more suspense as I found it to be effective. I also feel like the shark might have given up after hours of inactivity, I know they can smell blood from a mile away but come on, so as she puts her foot in the water and basically it's right there? And the whole ending was OK the way she gets the shark was different and creative but it seemed like everything up until he got onto that buoy turned into one of the most ridiculous series of events for a movie that took itself fairly serious throughout up until that. In summary, The Shallows in an enjoyable film, being aimed at people around the ages of 13-25 I imagine. But as a 33 year old man, I was only slightly impressed by the setup and the first shark encounter but anything after than I felt it went off back into familiar "shark movie" territory. The final act is just brimming with events way too far out of the realm of belief for me, regarding what the shark was doing was so unbelievable that it almost ruined the movie for me. *OVERALL I GIVE THE SHALLOWS A 6/10*

Review title: Really wanted this to be good.
Review_body: It was well worth the watch, I'll give it that. Solid acting, beautiful area and at least a modicum of shark fact to go with the wtf moments.Some of the facts that I see people complaining about actually make me cringe. I would love to see more movies like this. It was nothing like Jaws but seemed a bit more akin to The Reef.Whales bring in sharks, which lends credence to the appearance of a great white in a supposedly "no shark" area. The water lighting on fire made sense to me and...frankly using that chain to get to the anchor at the bottom? I wouldn't have had the guts.What I did NOT like, however, was the behavior of the shark itself. The single- minded Rogue mentality that has been debunked by the community of marine biology. Staying in one area for a long time makes sense with the whale carcass being present...but going after the humans like that? Of course it didn't eat them but then again...willing suspension of disbelief in those type of moments.The movie was worth the time to watch and I enjoyed it.I warn everyone to please keep an open mind for some of the glaringly obvious moments of disbelief in the film.

Review title: I know its for suspense but c'mon
Review_body: So I really like the previews for this movie, and was really excited to see this movie. But the director made this Great White way to aggressive. Up until we see Nancy's intentional and very scary attach was really liking the movie. After that the shark started to become fake. 1) True Whites will stick around area's wear there is food, and that whale carcass will provide food for days, but the shark will typically stick with that blubber for days, not bothering with drunks, or surfers. 2) Because of the whale carcass, the white will NOT put its self in jeopardy for food. The shark is scene doing this multiple times (almost beaching his self in the coral and eating the damn bu-wee)3) Whites in Mexico have not been known to breach this behavior has only been seen in South Africa. 4) Yes, the way this white has attacked its pry it could easily kill a human, but when a white attacks the first bit is known as an exploratory bit and 99.9% of the time when it bits a human it spits it out. So with that being said yes Nancy was 200 yards off shore, yes the first attack would of been horrible but what how that would of really gone is shark attacks Nancy, Nancy comes to the surface terrified, Nancy goes slowly gets herself safely back to shore the white shark goes back to eating his blubber rich whale carcass. Movie over.

Review title: One of the worst and shamefully unrealistic shark movies ever made
Review_body: It has been a while since a decent shark movie was made and I like Blake Lively as an actress so I was quite looking forward to this movie however, through no fault of her own, this was an atrociously bad film. With all the knowledge we now have of shark behavior through research over the decades since jaws was released, you just can't get away with making something that completely goes against everything we know.jaws was a masterpiece and still stands the tests of time so to see people comparing it to this movie, it baffles me. The idea of suspense seems to be lost on filmmakers these days, especially when it comes to shark movies. It's not worth the time

Review title: Great performance from Blake Lively against a terrifying shark!
Review_body: The Shallows was delightfully scary and riveting throughout the entire film. A few flaws I find that plague a lot of survival films have to do with that they are often quite long, and when there is a character in solitude, the lack of interaction with others can sometimes make a film boring or slow. This is not the case whatsoever in The Shallows which keeps the film a touch under an hour and a half. The entire point of survival films is well, that the protagonist survives, but despite that I was completely and utterly on edge during the vast majority of the movie. The race against time with the rising tide built up perfect tension, and I found the shark to be absolutely frightening! The concept of the story itself was original as well.I've been a fan of Blake Lively since she was on Gossip Girl and I think she has come a long way as an actress. Previously I thought she was good as the charismatic Serena van der Woodsen, but The Shallows is what really showcases her talent as Nancy. Even though she plays a similar charismatic fun-in-the-sun character, this time she is pretty much on her own as she acts almost entirely on her own throughout the entire movie opposite a CGI shark. That must have been quite challenging for her as an actress, and her performance was flawless. Dialogue was limited, but her range in expressions and emotions were certainly not lacking in the least.Nancy was an extremely clever character who repeatedly uses her wits in a setting that she otherwise would have had no experience with. She's a medical student who is able to apply her knowledge to help her survive a serious wound from a shark bite. This little bit of background knowledge helped round her character in a way that made sense.*****SPOILERS***** Although I think I would have enjoyed this film regardless of whether a man or a woman played the protagonist, that this was a female protagonist was just a little bit of a plus for me. As someone who has studied acting, I really appreciate it when films make some great roles for women. One thing I especially liked about Nancy as a character was that I really thought that someone else would save her in the movie. At any moment I was expecting a rescue helicopter to come save her, a pod of dolphins to come beat up the shark, anything. Instead she manages to outwit the shark and save herself.Although this is not the moment that kills the shark, my absolute favourite scene in the movie was when Nancy shoots a flare gun around the water of the dead whale and the shark is on fire for a brief moment. While the shark on fire was was quite a spectacular vision to behold and a truly great bit of CGI work, again I love how this showed that Nancy was truly a clever character for thinking about the oil that would have been coming from the whale.The only real issue I had was at the end when Nancy still has both legs. I really expected her to have lost the limb that was bitten. It was not a huge issue that this did not happen, but it would have made the ending just a little more powerful.I otherwise heavily recommend this movie, especially to fans of Jaws. I saw this with my boyfriend because Jaws is his favourite movie, and he really enjoyed it as well. As a summer flick it was a great thriller and I would definitely enjoy watching it again. I definitely plan to add it to my movie collection.

Review title: when you cant see the danger...
Review_body: I went into this films with low expectations but I was pleasantly surprised.I felt this on screen movie was better than the script which included a back story of Nancy's late mother. The movie touched on this but it wasn't littered with references like the script was. The movie flowed much better due to this.What "The Shallows" also got right was the reveal of the villain.The subtle references of what lurks beneath leads to a refreshing reveal - in which I must say is the best CGI incarnation there has been of a shark. Also, the shark, as the antagonist was directly set against the protagonist (Nancy). Again, rather than the usual mindless eating machine. But what the director got right most of all was the tension... no score - just the sound of the water. You are right with Nancy through all of her struggles and victories. No cut to "where's Nancy?" scenes showing bumbling friends etc.... Again, a refreshing change.The only thing which a found a moot point was the mystery of the location. It's referenced several times "what's this place called?" but you never find out, which kinds of defeats the object of it being referenced so many times throughout.You can tell the producers wanted a couple of "hollywood" moments in there which don't fit the tone of the story, but apart from that The Shallows is a fun film and definitely worth a watch.

Review title: A seamless Jaws of the year
Review_body: A solo character, Nancy, starred by Blake Lively, has made history in facing her fear in the shallows. Despite the simplicity of the film, it perfectly illustrates the abundance of ideas and genre of this motion picture, a thrill, from the beginning to the end of the film. It will get you on the edge of your seat, wondering what is going to happen next. Without a lot of script and characters, this film has successfully and poignantly portrayed the beauty of an island, a no-name island, with a shark lurking in the shallows. Every bit of the soundtrack seamlessly illustrates the motion picture. It is definitely a must to see it on the silver screen if you're a big fan of, first, Blake Lively; second, sharks; and survival of the fittest.
At the end, she should have entered into the water glad to be over her PTSD and physically healed. Then, a shark should have burst up in a fountain of water and eaten her. The End.

On the good side cgi and special effects are well made and some of the images of the beach and the ocean are stunning. The acting is good giving a sense of immersion and overall the viewer definitely experiences the terror inflicted by the shark on the protagonist. The movie is a good survival story and i would recommend watching it. But i don't think it's a must see in a theater. You can totally watch it home and this is why:When i took a look at the budget before seeing the movie i knew they couldn't allow themselves to integrate too much action scenes including cgi. To counter this, they needed a very good script. This is where the movie falls short of expectations in my opinion. The story is much too simple to be the sole plot of an entire movie. To counter that a lot of emphasis is placed on the emotional side of the story. At some points it gets a little boring, you have the feeling that those simplistic scenes (budget wise) were thrown in solely to enable a minimal duration of 1 hour and a half long for the movie. I was therefore a bit disappointed and still hungering for more since not much is happening unfortunately, even with a quite short movie. But still i recommend watching it at home it's worth your time.

The idea is decent, the initial execution is adequate and suspenseful, but the ending is sheer stupidity. The kind that ruins the movie. Whoever approved this ending at the studio (Columbia Pictures) should be ashamed of themselves -- but they're probably too busy counting the dollars as this film was, unfortunately, a commercial success. I'm inclined to write the studio to get back my $3 for the rental, as it wasn't even worth that. In fact, perhaps I should ask to be paid for the two hours that I wasted watching the film. Tons of other shark movies are way more satisfying than this one. And that includes Jaws IV.

The Shallows is a perfect example of how to make a perfectly competent and thrilling shark movie from the moment the camera opens onto the beautiful Mexican beaches to the very end once the last of the credits has rolled. The cast (which is very small, good for this kind of movie) is led by a beautiful Blake Lively; none of the others are of particular significance. Lively stars as Texan medical student Nancy, who has determined it's time to take a little R & R and takes a trip to a idyllic Mexican coast. Before long, however, she becomes the victim of a shark attack and, alone, save for the company of a seagull, the movie is a harrowing tale of man, er, woman versus nature at its finest. Lively proves to be a great choice as the lead. She has a charisma, vulnerability, and resourcefulness that I believe is ideal in the heroines of this genre of film; bold and plucky, she manages to keep a smile on her face (much of the time), with an attitude that seems to say, "gimme your best shot." It is riveting to watch her scramble to stay alive, determined not to lose to what appears to be the very hand of Fate itself. This movie does what any shark movie that is worth its salt does best, that is, besides possessing a great number of fake-outs and an ominous, looming score, it contrasts the beauty of its surroundings with the horrors that lurk beneath. And the location is part of what makes this movie so very, very good. If it weren't for the shark, I'd want to dive right into those cool, blue waters. The cinematographer does a wonderful job of showing how indisputably beautiful the Mexican coasts are (and how unforgiving). The shark itself is a CGI spectacle, looking just like the real thing. And while it lacks the threatening presence of Jaws, it nevertheless makes for a wonderful foe for Lively. It is intelligent and *seems* to be gunning for Lively, its determination unsettling and beyond natural, dare I say, purposeful. And though there is one moment which I believe "jumps the shark" just a bit, it leads to one of the best, kick-ass endings I've seen in recent cinema. My only major complaint is that during some of the early surfing sequences, the action goes from slow to fast to slow again one-too-many times, and some of the beginning scenes linger a little too long. But these are easily forgettable, as the rest of the film's 87-minute run-time is unrelenting intensity from the point where the camera emerges from the murky depths in classic, Jaws-like fashion. THIS is the Jaws sequel we should've gotten. I *do* recommend wading into The Shallows.8/10

Review title: Why did Blake Lively agree to this horseshit?

But this is nothing more than a stain on her otherwise great resume. The movie has no substance. We don't even really care for any of the characters and we're not afraid of the shark. Review title: A Short Thriller That Will Keep You On the Edge of Your Seat (SPOILERS)
Review_body: For my love and interest towards sharks, I was very much looking forward to this movie. Ever since the trailer was released I have been waiting desperately for the special date of June 24. So yes, I may be biased because it is a shark movie and about something I like, but in a seriousness, the Shallows is a good movie. Some may argue: "Oh, a shark that size would never be able to jump out of the water in areas that shallow," or "A shark would never stick around to make sure it consumes the last human in the area, and would not relentlessly continue to kill everyone that enters the water". Yes most of these complaints and arguments may be true, but that is just to drive the plot, for if the shark went away, that would be the end of the movie and hundreds of unhappy moviegoers would leave the theater asking for a refund and saying, "That wasn't exciting at all! She just disturbed the shark, waited on a rock for 2 days until the shark was gone and swam back to shore!"So without the great white's grudge for Blake Lively, who disturbed the shark's feeding grounds (A deceased 200 ton blue whale) there would be no movie, suspense, or action.Moving on, as for the movie, it was beautifully shot. The scenery was amazing, blue (it's an ocean of course), and colorful. The acting was laudable, for Blake Lively's performance was well crafted (It's very hard to act without talking much), and the other actors did fine as well.As for the shark, the CGI was overall very good, compared to other shark horror movies where the sharks are literally all animated as if they were in Pixar cartoons. Yes I'm talking about Deep Blue Sea. God, what an abomination of a movie. Anyways, a lot of effort was put in to creating the main antagonist, and for the most part, the shark was very believable, especially when it breached out of the water and attacked the two surfers, *shivers*.I only have three magical complaints for the entire movie, which unfortunately was 87 minutes long... eh I guess we'll add that as a complaint. The movie was too short for my taste. My first complaint was that I did not like when Ms. Lively was skyping her family and the screen of the phone was displayed like a hologram facing the audience. It was quite corny and found it to be light and unrealistic.My second complaint is that there was not enough exposition and the rising action and climax came too quickly. This would've made the movie longer, yes, and possibly more interesting. For instance, give some more backstory on how Ms. Lively lost her mother or if you don't want to extend the exposition, make other conflicts happen while she is stranded on the rock. Maybe a canoe can come across or a life raft and the shark eats it, I don't know! I am not a film writer!Finally, the ending! TOO PREDICTABLE! She kills the shark in the most insane way, although cool... COMPLETELY INSANE! She grabs a weighted chain, unhooks it from the buoy, and plummets down with a shark on her tail. Suddenly she releases the chain, after plummeting a hundred or so feet and the shark is impaled by the pole connected to the chain. Poor shark. What made me really want to see the movie was in one of the trailers, the announcer said "you have no idea how this will end", when indeed I did have the right idea... the shark dies and Ms. Lively makes it to shore safe. Throw a twist ending! Make it tragic. In order to kill the shark she must take her own life, so they both die, now that would've been cool.In conclusion, the Shallows is a remarkable film that has loads of suspense, thrills and action. I would definitely recommend it. but it is most likely a film you would only watch once or twice. Overall, it deserves a good rating
